This is some "philosophizing" I started today. 
 
 Life and the Requirement of Reproduction?
 
 What is life? There are several ways of defining it, but one of the most common is by listing a set of shared, fundamental characteristics of all living organisms. Different sources list different characteristics, but most lists contain the following five: responsiveness (irritability), growth (development), reproduction, movement, and metabolism. But there are some living organisms that do not posses all of these properties. The particular characteristic I will focus on is reproduction.
 
 Inductive Logic Fails to Show that Reproduction is a Requirement of Life
 The view that reproduction is a required characteristic of life can be viewed as a conclusion reached by inductive logic. If we look at humans, which are alive, we see that they reproduce. If we look at dogs, which are alive, we see that they reproduce. The same goes for cats, birds, snakes, lizards, frogs, flies, worms, fish, squids, yeast, paramecia, E. coli, and so on: they are all alive and they all reproduce. But all inductive arguments hold absolutely only as long as no exception is found. A single counterexample is sufficient to disprove an inductive argument, and this particular 'pro-reproductionist' argument fails because of the stubborn mule. When a horse and a donkey are crossed, the resulting offspring is a mule, which, as a rule, cannot reproduce. Yet mules are surely alive. So we see that it is not an absolute requirement for something to be able to reproduce in order for it to be alive.
 
 Reasoning Fails to Show that Reproduction is a Requirement of Life
 Since the inductive method fails to hold, is there a reasoned, logical requirement for living things to reproduce? Most would say yes. Their first argument might go something like this: 
 
 
If living things didn't reproduce, then life would quickly disappear. 

 
 While that may be true, it fails to show that reproduction is a requirement in order to call something living: that living things would disappear as a result of their not reproducing doesn't show that they are not living before they disappear. 
 
 
 [start: added 01/01/2006]
 In fact, even with reproduction, organisms - such as leopards, elephants, whales, and so on - will eventually die out. Does that mean that they are not living organisms now? Of course not.
 [end: added 01/01/2006]
 
 
 The "pro-reproductionists" second attempt, and improvement on the first, might go something like this: 
 
 
If living things didn't reproduce, then life would quickly disappear: and since life has existed continuously on Earth for nearly four billions years, then life must be able to reproduce. 

 
 While that may be true of life in general, all it really logically entails is that SOME - not all - organisms throughout all of life's history were able to reproduce. And at a smaller scale, it does not apply to any individual organism: it doesn't tell us that in order for organism X to be considered living that it must reproduce (take for example, mules). 
 
 Must All Living Organisms Die?
 An implicit assumption in the last several arguments is that all living things must die. After all, if a living organism didn't die, then it wouldn't need to reproduce in order to persist, even for 4 billion years. We need to ask, "Does this assumption of universal death hold?" Yes, well, at least for all instances of life that we currently know of. Thus, it is a conclusion based on induction, not on necessity. 
 
 Consider a species capable of repairing itself indefinitely. Sound far fetched? Well, we humans ourselves are desiring to do just that. And to an extremely limited degree, we have succeeded. Of course, we still have an enormous distance left before fully succeeding, but if we were to eventually do so, then could it really be said that reproduction is a requirement to consider humans as being alive? No. We'd be like "immortal mules": we'd be alive, yet incapable of reproducing ... but unlike mules, we wouldn't need to be continually replaced by reproduction. After all, we could stop reproducing (women might really like that idea!) and instead focus on repairing those that currently exist.
 
 Perhaps, though, we "immortal mules", by simply repairing ourselves and maintaining the status quo, would still somehow die: after all, nature shows us that those organisms that don't adapt to the ever changing conditions on Earth just don't last. Perhaps the changes in our environment would be too dramatic to be handled by simply replacing what is damaged with a new part. This line of reasoning fails since our intent is not simply to repair ourselves, but to improve ourselves as well. Humans intend to direct their own bodily evolution, either via installed hardware or through genetic manipulations, adapting our bodies to changes in the environment. 
 
 And if we ever reach this ultimate goal (is it a good goal?!), then we could save energy by modifying our bodies to eliminate the no-longer-required processes involved in reproduction . 
 
 Conclusion
 Based on the above lines of reason, I assert that reproduction is not an absolute requirement of life: that something could be considered to be alive without it necessarily needing to be able to reproduce.

Okay, what about Asimo? 
 
 Asimo is Honda's humanoid robot (http://world.honda.com/ASIMO/new/). It has a head, body, two jointed arms and two jointed legs, and can walk - even up stairs, run - even cornering while running, carry and hand off objects to others, can recognize and interact with people, and so on.
 
 Okay, now I admit that Asimo is not living ... YET! For example, a human must charge it and then it will run for only about 40 minutes. But consider a future Asimo robot that was self-sustaining (perhaps by using solar power and fuel cells - who knows?) - why could it not be considered living? 
 
 When considering whether or not robots can be considered living, the shared fundamental characteristics of life seem to me to break down. 
 
 1) Reproduction. This has already been addressed above. It has been tentatively accepted that reproduction is not required in order to consider something as living. And with robots, 'eternal life' and 'evolution' through maintenance and upgrades is considerably more plausible than it is for the hypothetical humans I discussed.
 
 2) Metabolism. Is metabolism really required in order to consider something living? This, like most of the other fundamental characteristics of life, appears to be in the list based on INDUCTIVE reasoning. But we can surely ask, what if the FUNCTION metabolism performs - obtaining and utilizing energy to maintain the system and power its movements and actions - were achieved but without the standard biochemical reactions? Would that be sufficient?
 
 3) Growth/Development. Is growth/delevopment really required in order to consider something living? This too appears to be in the list of shared fundamental characteristics of life based on INDUCTIVE reasoning. Why MUST something grow/develop in order to be considered living? 
 
 Also, a potential counter example exists in biology: during very early embryonic development, the blastomeres that result from cleavage do not grow inbetween successive rounds of division: instead, the original egg cytoplam is subdivided into more and more, smaller and smaller, cells. These cells don't grow, but are surely alive. Perhaps it could be argued that they develop (since they pass through a set of stages), but that might be pushing the idea of development to an extreme.
 
 
 
 I'll stop at these three for now.
